title: Integrative analysis of mitochondrial metabolic dynamics in reprogramming human fibroblast cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Real-time metabolic analysis of human fibroblasts
Timing: 2 days
Below we provide a detailed step-by-step protocol about the real-time metabolic analysis of reprogramming human fibroblasts by using Seahorse XF HS Mini Analyzer.
Alternatives: This protocol includes the use of a commercial kit (Seahorse XFp Cell Mito Stress Test Kit from Agilent Technologies). However, users can perform the experiment using in-house made stock solutions (Zhang et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]).
Plating fibroblasts onto an XF HS miniplate.
Seed human fibroblasts onto wells B-G of the XF HS miniplate containing 100 μL of fibroblast medium at 5∼6 × 103 cells/well (∼90% confluency).
Critical: When seeding, make sure to uniformly disperse the cells at the bottom of the well. Do not seed the cells on wells A and H of the miniplate as these are for blank/background correction.
Incubate the XF HS miniplate in the 5% CO2 37°C incubator for 18–24 h.
Hydrating sensor cartridge.
Put cartridges into the laminar flow hood.
Separate the sensor cartridge from the utility plate and place the sensor cartridge upside down.
Add 200 μL of XF Calibrant solution into each well of the Utility plate.
Add 400 μL of XF Calibrant solution into the moat chambers around the outside of the wells.
Return the XF Sensor cartridge to the Utility plate containing XF Calibrant solution.
Place the cartridge assembly in a non-CO2 37°C incubator for 18–24 h.
Critical: The non-CO2 37°C incubator should be kept humidified at 100% to prevent evaporation of the XF Calibrant solution.
Preparing XF HS miniplate for assay.
Next day, verify the condition of the cells in the XF HS miniplate before starting the assay ensuring the cells are well distributed.
Note: Make sure the cells are well-attached at 80%–90% density as single cells, not as aggregates.

Turn on the XF HS Mini Analyzer at least 1 h before the experiment.
Prepare 5 mL of XF assay medium for each 8-well XF HS miniplate and warm it up in a 37°C water bath.
Aspirate the fibroblast media from the XF HS miniplate containing fibroblasts without disturbing the cells.
Gently wash out each well of the XF HS miniplate twice with 180 μL of XF assay medium.
Add 180 μL of XF assay medium into each well of the XF HS miniplate and put the plate into the non-CO2 37°C incubator for 1 h.
Preparing compounds for loading sensor cartridge.
After 20 min, reconstitute compounds with pre-warmed XF assay medium.
Dilute the reconstituted compounds with pre-warmed XF assay medium.
Note: We suggest using 2 μM FCCP as a final concentration. However, the optimal dose of FCCP may vary depending on cell context. Determine and identify the optimal FCCP concentration to provoke maximal respiration of your cells.
Move a hydrated sensor cartridge assembly from the non-CO2 37°C incubator to the laminar flow hood and load the diluted compounds into the indicated ports of the hydrated sensor cartridge.
Add 20 μL of diluted oligomycin solution into Port A of the hydrated sensor cartridge.
Add 22 μL of diluted FCCP solution into Port B of the hydrated sensor cartridge.
Add 25 μL of diluted rotenone/antimycin A solution into Port C of the hydrated sensor cartridge.
Note: Port D of the hydrated sensor cartridge should be empty unless users want to test their own chemicals.
Hit ‘START’ and run the ‘Mito Stress Test’ program of the XF HS Mini Analyzer.
Place the compounds-loaded, hydrated sensor cartridge assembly onto the load position of XF HS Mini Analyzer.
Note: See the user manual for operation details of the XF HS Mini Analyzer (https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/user-manual-flux-analyzer-xf-hs-mini-extracellular-5994-1961en-agilent.pdf[href=https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/user-manual-flux-analyzer-xf-hs-mini-extracellular-5994-1961en-agilent.pdf]).

Running metabolic analysis.
Once the calibration step of the hydrated sensor cartridge is completed, switch the Utility plate with the XF HS miniplate containing cells and click ‘CONTINUE’.
Determining protein concentration.
Once the assay is completed, take out the assayed XF HS miniplate from the cartridge-miniplate assembly and carefully aspirate the medium from each well of the miniplate without disturbing the attached cells.
Wash out the cells with 200 μL of DPBS once.
After aspirating DPBS, add 200 μL of Bradford dye reagent into each well of the miniplate and mix well to prepare a crude cell lysate.
Measure each sample optical density with a spectrometer to assess the protein concentration.
Alternatives: In this protocol, we used a Synergy HTX multi-mode reader. However, spectrometers from different providers also work with this protocol.
Analyzing data.
Analyze raw data using the Seahorse WAVE Desktop software.
Note: See the user manual for operation details of the WAVE software (https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/S7894-10000_Rev_C_Wave_2_6_User_Guide.pdf[href=https://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/S7894-10000_Rev_C_Wave_2_6_User_Guide.pdf]).
The following factors can be presented as a result of real-time metabolic analysis.
Oxygen consumption rate (OCR; pmol/min/μg protein).
Extracellular acidification rate (ECAR; mpH/min/μg protein).
OCR/ECAR ratio.
Basal respiration = baseline OCR – rotenone/antimycin A OCR.
Maximal respiration = FCCP OCR – rotenone/antimycin A OCR.
ATP turnover = baseline OCR – oligomycin OCR.
Oxidative reserve = maximal respiration – basal respiration.
OCR changes after FCCP injection.
Quantification of mitochondrial network
Timing: 3 days
Below we provide a detailed step-by-step protocol for the quantification of mitochondrial network by immunostaining analysis.
Preparing samples.
Plate fibroblasts onto the 4-chamber cell culture slide at 2.5∼3 × 105 cells/well (∼80% confluency) and incubate in a 5% CO2 37°C incubator for 18–24 h.
Next day, wash out the chamber slide containing fibroblasts with 1 mL of DPBS twice.

Aspirate the DPBS and fix the cells for 10 min with 0.5 mL of 10% formaldehyde solution.
Aspirate the formaldehyde solution and wash out the cells three times for 10 min with 1 mL of DPBS.
Pause point: If you do not have enough time to stain the cells, fill the chamber slide with 1 mL of DPBS, seal with parafilm, and store it at 4°C for up to 1 week.
Aspirate the DPBS and incubate the cells for 30 min with 1 mL of blocking solution.
Aspirate the blocking solution and incubate the cells with anti-TOM20 antibody in blocking solution at 4°C for 18–24 h on a shaker.
Next day, aspirate the diluted antibody solution and wash the cells three times for 10 min with 1 mL of washing solution.
Aspirate the washing solution and incubate the cells for 1 h on a shaker at room temperature (15°C–30°C) with anti-mouse secondary antibody in blocking solution.
Aspirate the diluted antibody solution and wash the cells three times for 10 min with 1 mL of washing solution.
Aspirate the washing solution and incubate the cells for 5 min with 500 μL of Hoechst 33342 in DPBS at room temperature (15°C–30°C).
Aspirate the diluted Hoechst 33342 solution, wash the cells three times for 10 min with 1 mL of DPBS.
Aspirate the DPBS, remove the chamber from the slide.
Apply one drop of Fluoroshield solution onto the slide and cover it with a microscope cover glass.
Once the Fluoroshield is dry, image the slide under a fluorescence microscope.
Quantifying mitochondrial network.
Download and install software including the Fiji distribution of ImageJ2 software (https://imagej.net/software/fiji/[href=https://imagej.net/software/fiji/]) and the Mitochondrial Network Analysis (MiNA; https://github.com/StuartLab/MiNA[href=https://github.com/StuartLab/MiNA]) toolset.
Perform the ‘MiNA Analyze Morphology’ script by navigating to the ‘StuartLab’ under the ‘Plugins’ menu of the Fiji software.

Process the acquired image with the ‘MiNA Analyze Morphology’ script as described below (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]):
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1648-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Setting up the ‘MiNA Analyze Morphology’ plugin for quantifying mitochondrial network
Set up ‘Unsharp Mask’ as 1st place.
Set up ‘Enhance Local Contrast CLAHE’ as 2nd place.
Set up ‘Median Filter’ as 3rd place.
Select ‘Preview Preprocessing’ function.
Perform the script by pressing the ‘OK’ button.
The following factors can be quantified from the parameters released from processing with MiNA.
Mitochondrial footprint (μm2).
Summed branch length (μm).
Assessment of mitochondrial mass
Timing: 2 h
Below we provide a detailed step-by-step protocol on how to perform the measurement of mitochondrial mass by flow cytometry analysis. We recommend adding CCCP as a positive control for assessing mitochondrial mass.
Preparing samples.
Collect the cells grown on 6 cm tissue culture dish at ∼80% confluency (up to 1 × 106 cells) by using TrypLE™ express enzyme solution.
Spin down the cells at 200 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the medium and wash the cells with 1 mL of DPBS twice.
Aspirate the DPBS and incubate the cells with MitoTracker™ Green FM (150 nM in DPBS) for 25 min at 37°C.
Spin down the cells at 200 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the MitoTracker™ Green FM solution and wash the cells with 1 mL of DPBS twice.
Reconstitute the cells with 1 mL of DPBS.
Measuring mitochondrial mass.
Measure the mitochondrial mass using a MACSQuant® Analyzer 16.
Note: See the user manual for details to operate the MACSQuant® Analyzer 16 (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/_Resources/Persistent/931639a5b475f080764f13e26d034cbb857a1c9c/MACSQuant%20Instrument%20user%20manual.pdf[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/_Resources/Persistent/931639a5b475f080764f13e26d034cbb857a1c9c/MACSQuant%20Instrument%20user%20manual.pdf]).
Analyze the raw data using FlowJo.
Note: See the user manual for details to analyze flow cytometry data using FlowJo (https://f.hubspotusercontent20.net/hubfs/2566672/Marketing/Flowjo_Introduction.pdf[href=https://f.hubspotusercontent20.net/hubfs/2566672/Marketing/Flowjo_Introduction.pdf]).
The following factors can be presented based on assessment of mitochondrial mass.
Mean fluorescence intensity (MFI).
Assessment of mitochondrial membrane potential

Timing: 2 h
Below we provide a detailed step-by-step protocol on how to measure mitochondrial membrane potential by flow cytometry analysis.
Preparing samples.
Collect the cells grown on 6 cm tissue culture dish at ∼80% confluency (up to 1 × 106 cells) by using TryPLE™ express enzyme solution.
Spin down the cells at 200 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the medium and wash the cells with 1 mL of DPBS twice.
Aspirate the DPBS and incubate the cells with JC-1 cationic dye (10 μg/mL in DPBS) for 10 min at 37°C.
Spin down the cells at 200 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the JC-1 solution and wash the cells with 1 mL of DPBS twice.
Reconstitute the cells with 1 mL of DPBS.
Measuring mitochondrial membrane potential.
Measure the mitochondrial membrane potential using a MACSQuant® Analyzer 16.
Note: See the user manual for details to operate the MACSQuant® Analyzer 16 (see above).
Analyze the raw data using FlowJo.
Note: See the user manual for details to analyze flow cytometry data using FlowJo (see above).
The following factors can be presented as a result of assessment of mitochondrial membrane potential.
Ratio of green fluorescence (emitted at 525 nm by JC-1 monomers) vs. red fluorescence (emitted at 590 nm by JC-1 aggregates).
Measurement of mitochondrial metabolites
Timing: 2–3 h
Below we provide a detailed step-by-step protocol on measuring mitochondrial metabolites by using metabolite-specific colorimetric assay kit (all from BioVision).
Note: See the user manual for details on how to perform the mitochondrial metabolites assay.
Preparing samples.
Collect the cells grown on 6 cm tissue culture dish at ∼80% confluency (up to 1 × 106 cells) by using a cell lifter.

Transfer the cell suspension into a 15 mL conical tube and spin down the cells at 200 × g for 3 min.
Aspirate the medium and resuspend the cells with 1 mL of DPBS.
Transfer the cell suspension into a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube and spin down the cells at 6,000 × g for 1 min.
Aspirate the DPBS and lyse the cells with 100 μL of 1× Cell Lysis buffer on ice for 30 min.
Alternatives: For the lysis step, 1× RIPA buffer (Cat# 9806; Cell Signaling Technologies) can be used instead of 1× Cell Lysis buffer.
Centrifuge the lysed cells at 15,000 × g, 4°C for 10 min.
Transfer the lysate carefully into new 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube without disturbing cell pellet and store the samples on ice.
Pause point: Cell lysates can be stored at −20°C until use.
Measure the protein concentration of samples with a spectrometer using a Bradford assay.
Measuring mitochondrial metabolites.
Add 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 μL of diluted standard solution into a series of standards wells on a 96-well microplate.
Add 50, 48, 46, 44, 42, 40 μL of Assay buffer into the wells of the 96-well microplate containing the standards to adjust the volume to 50 μL/well.
Add 1–50 μL of samples into duplicate wells of the 96-well microplate.
Add Assay buffer into the sample wells of the 96-well microplate to adjust the volume to 50 μL/well.
Add 50 μL of the Reaction mix solution to each well of the 96-well microplate containing the standards and samples.
Incubate the microplate in a non-CO2 37°C incubator for 30 min.
Measure the OD values of samples on a microplate reader at appropriate wavelengths as described below:
450 nm for malate.
570 nm for citrate, α-ketoglutarate, and oxaloacetate.

For kinetic readings, repeat the microplate incubation at 37°C and measure the OD values at 20 min intervals up to 1 h.
Analyzing data.
Calculate metabolite concentrations of each sample from the recorded OD values for the standard solution and samples as below:
C = Ay / Sy (nmol/μg protein).
Ay: amount of metabolite (nmol) in samples from the standard curve.
Sy: amount of samples (μg) added to the sample well.
The data can be presented as heatmaps, scatter plot or bar charts.
